node.text:
“It’s just burnt the pastures right up.”

Canada's prairie provinces - agricultural heartlands - have been hit hard by drought. 

In the face of climate change, ranchers like Ryan Boyd are experimenting with new ways to work with nature and its extremes.

#Canada #Drought #BBCNews

node.title: Canadian prairie ranchers struggle with drought conditions

node.text:
Since the start of the pandemic, there’s been an increase in the production and smuggling of fake medicines around the world.

Authorities are cracking down on this type of crime and we were given exclusive access to a global operation led by World Customs in Benin in West Africa. 

The market for fake drugs is worth around $200bn worldwide every year. 

Since the operation began World Customs say it has seized more than 307 million illegal medicine items. 99.5% of them were discovered in West and Central Africa.

#Benin #BBCNews

node.title: On the trail of fake drug smugglers

node.text:
“I blame Larry Nasser, and I also blame an entire system that enabled and perpetrated his abuse.”

Elite US athlete Simone Biles has testified before the US Senate about abuse she suffered at the hands of the disgraced former team doctor.

"How much is a little girl worth?" asked Ms Biles, the most decorated Olympic gymnast of all-time.

Former teammates Aly Raisman and McKayla Maroney also appeared before the committee, along with FBI Director Christopher Wray.

The committee is examining shortcomings in the FBI's investigation into Nassar, who was convicted of sexually abusing girls. A report found numerous missteps and cover-ups by FBI agents, which allowed Nassar's abuse to continue for months after the case was first opened.

Tap the link in our bio to find out what the FBI said at the hearing.

#SimoneBiles #BBCNews

node.title: Olympic gymnasts give powerful testimony about abuse

node.text:
As governments such as the UK transition to ‘zero carbon’, countries will see the formation of new industries and ‘green’ jobs which didn’t exist a generation ago.

This transition will be a key issue at the COP26 climate talks in Glasgow in November.

Beth, 21, is a research assistant at a vertical farm which uses renewable energy to grow crops which are then sold locally.

Bridie, 23, used to work in hospitality but is now retraining as an apprentice offshore wind turbine technician.

#ClimateChange #COP26 #BBCNews

node.title: Are these the green jobs of the future?

node.text:
Esha is a four-year-old girl with leukaemia who has been given only weeks to live unless she can find a stem cell donor.

After being diagnosed with leukaemia back in May, her family are desperately looking for South Asians in London who can save her life – but it is proving difficult.

They are organising drop-in testing centres around the UK to try and find a match.

#Leukaemia  #Cancer #BBCNews

node.title: The 4-year-old searching for South Asian bone marrow donors

node.text:
In Russia, ahead of this week’s parliamentary and local elections, many opposition candidates have been prevented from running, and some even forced to flee.

The authorities insist the vote will be free and fair and deny claims it will be rigged in favour of the ruling party United Russia.

Some of the politicians barred from the ballot spoke to the BBC in Siberia and Bulgaria.

#Russia #Putin #BBCNews

node.text:
“If climate change continues this way, then the city you live in would be uninhabitable. My question is - how can you let that happen?”

In 2015, a heatwave in Karachi, Pakistan killed 1,200 people but one man is trying to help cool the city by planting urban forests. 🌳🌳🌳

Tap the link in our bio for more on how extreme heat is affecting lives across the world.

#ClimateChange #Pakistan #BBCNews

node.text:
One of fashion's biggest and most star-studded events, The Met Gala rolled out its red carpet in New York for some of the planet's best-known celebrities. 🤩

Lil Nas X, Billie Eilish, Naomi Osaka and Kim Kardashian were just some of the stars that turned up to dazzle.

The event, which raises funds for the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Costume Institute, was cancelled in 2020 due to Covid.

#MetGala #MetGala2021 #Fashion #NewYork #BBCNews

node.title: Celebrities show off lavish Met Gala outfits in New York

node.text:
Climate change has had a devastating impact on Nigeria. 

Fertile lands are turning into deserts in the north, while flash floods have become more common in the south.

Nigeria’s oil industry is making the situation worse, as the practice of flaring - the burning of natural gas that is released when oil is extracted from the ground - is common, despite being illegal, and is a major source of greenhouse gases and a contributor to climate change.

Joy and her family are among two million Nigerians living within 4km of a gas flare in the country’s oil-rich south.

#Nigeria #ClimateChange #BBCNews

node.title: The toxic gas flares fuelling Nigeria's climate change

node.text:
In the wake of the 9/11 terror attacks, the US saw a sharp rise in hate crimes. The attackers targeted those they believed to be Arab Muslims.

The innocent victims included Balbir Singh Sodhi, an American-Sikh who had a beard and wore a turban and ran the family gas station in Mesa, Arizona.

His murder, four days after 9/11, was the first racially-motivated hate crime in the backlash of the attacks.

The BBC spoke to Balbir's brother, and for the first time, his son and the gunman.

#911 #US #BBCNews

node.title: 'My dad was killed in the first hate-crime after 9/11'

node.text:
"She was incredible and absolutely so beautiful."

In April, former footballer and reality TV star Ashley Cain and his partner, Safiyya Vorajee, lost their eight-month-old daughter Azaylia to leukaemia.

The couple told @ashleyjbaptiste about their experiences of dealing with grief and bereavement – and urged other people going through similar pain to "talk about it".

Ashley is currently riding 1,000 miles to raise more money for the childhood cancer foundation the couple launched.

If you, or someone you know, has been affected by this story you can get support, information and advice from BBC Action Line: https://www.bbc.co.uk/actionline/

#Leukaemia #BBCNews

node.title: Ashley Cain on baby daughter's death

node.text:
North Korea says this is its new train-launched missile system.
 
Pictures from state media claim to show it carrying out a ballistic missile test.
 
The country says the missiles flew around 500 miles (800 km) at targets in the sea off the country's east coast.
 
UN resolutions ban North Korea from carrying out tests with ballistic missiles - which can carry either nuclear or conventional warheads - in efforts to curb the country's nuclear programme.
 
Tap the link in our bio to read the full story.
 
#NorthKorea #BBCNews

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by BBC News on September 16, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'BBC NEWS Newly-discovered Newly- Van Gogh drawing goes on display'.

node.text:
A previously unseen Vincent Van Gogh drawing has been discovered, a museum dedicated to the artist has confirmed. 🖼️
 
Study for Worn Out showing an exhausted old man was drawn early in the artist's career in 1882, the Van Gogh Museum said.
 
Tap the link in our bio to find out more about the sketch which has been been sitting in a Dutch family's private collection for more than a century.
 
It went on display at the museum in Amsterdam for the first time on Thursday.
 
The public will be able to see it until 2 January, before it is returned to the private collection.

(📷 Reuters)

#VanGogh #Art #BBCNews

node.text:
“It’s just burnt the pastures right up.”

Canada's prairie provinces - agricultural heartlands - have been hit hard by drought. 

In the face of climate change, ranchers like Ryan Boyd are experimenting with new ways to work with nature and its extremes.

#Canada #Drought #BBCNews

node.text:
These amazing images are all winners or runners up at this year’s Mangrove Photography Awards. 📸 🌱

The competition aims to show the relationships between wildlife, coastal communities and mangrove forests, as well as the fragility of these unique ecosystems, both above and below the waterline.

There were 1,300 entries from 65 countries, with Musfiqur Rahman named overall winner for his photograph of a wild honey gatherer subduing giant honeybees with smoke, in Bangladesh.

Tap the link in our bio to see more beautiful shots. 
 
(📷 Mangrove Photography Awards, photographer credits below)

Photo 1 - Musfiqur Rahman, Bangladesh (Overall winner)
Photo 2 - Hooreya Al Muflahi, UAE
Photo 3 - Leo Liu, Taiwan
Photo 4 - Arijit Das, India
Photo 5 - Lorenzo Mittiga, Netherlands Antilles
Photo 6 - Dhany Darmansyah Saragih, Indonesia
Photo 7 - Lucas Oh Hao Xiang, Singapore 
Photo 8 - Abhijit Chakraborty, India
Photo 9 - Zohaib Anjum, UAE

node.text:
Since the start of the pandemic, there’s been an increase in the production and smuggling of fake medicines around the world.

Authorities are cracking down on this type of crime and we were given exclusive access to a global operation led by World Customs in Benin in West Africa. 

The market for fake drugs is worth around $200bn worldwide every year. 

Since the operation began World Customs say it has seized more than 307 million illegal medicine items. 99.5% of them were discovered in West and Central Africa.

#Benin #BBCNews

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by BBC News on September 16, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'BBC BBCN NEWS Australian bandicoot brought back from the brink of extinction'.

node.text:
A small furry marsupial has been brought back from the brink of extinction, officials in Australia say.

The Eastern Barred Bandicoot used to roam the grassy plains of Australia's Victoria state but animals from other countries like foxes, habitat destruction and feral cats caused their numbers to plummet.

Over the last 30 years, conservation teams have invested millions of dollars into setting up breeding programmes and creating protected areas, guarded with dogs.

It is the first time Australia has changed the status of an animal from "extinct in the wild" to "endangered”, as the numbers have gone up from 150 to an estimated 1500.

To read more about how they helped bring the Bandicoot back from the brink, tap the link in our bio.

(📷 Getty Images)

#Australia #Conservation #Animals #BBCNews

node.text:
Four amateur astronauts have blasted off from Florida on a private all-civilian mission to orbit, after billionaire Jared Issacman bought four seats - for himself and three "ordinary citizens". 

The Inspiration4 crew rode out of the Kennedy Space Center in a Dragon capsule provided by Elon Musk’s SpaceX rocket company.

The quartet will spend the next three days circling the Earth, in another milestone in the space tourism market. 

Earlier this summer, billionaire businessmen Sir Richard Branson and Jeff Bezos went above Earth's atmosphere in their own space vehicles.

The Inspiration4 crew of Issacman, Hayley Arceneaux, Sian Proctor and Chris Sembroski have had six months of intensive training with SpaceX. However, onboard computer systems will be in control of their Dragon capsule, overseen by SpaceX teams on the ground.

Tap the link in our bio on why Issacman selected these people as his crew instead of going on an “outing with fishing buddies”. 

(📸: Reuters)

#Space #BBCNews

node.text:
“I blame Larry Nasser, and I also blame an entire system that enabled and perpetrated his abuse.”

Elite US athlete Simone Biles has testified before the US Senate about abuse she suffered at the hands of the disgraced former team doctor.

"How much is a little girl worth?" asked Ms Biles, the most decorated Olympic gymnast of all-time.

Former teammates Aly Raisman and McKayla Maroney also appeared before the committee, along with FBI Director Christopher Wray.

The committee is examining shortcomings in the FBI's investigation into Nassar, who was convicted of sexually abusing girls. A report found numerous missteps and cover-ups by FBI agents, which allowed Nassar's abuse to continue for months after the case was first opened.

Tap the link in our bio to find out what the FBI said at the hearing.

#SimoneBiles #BBCNews

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by BBC News on September 15, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'BBCNES NEWS "I blame Larry Nasser, and I also blame an entire system that enabled and perpetrated his abuse" Simone Biles'.

node.text:
Elite gymnast Simone Biles has testified before the US Senate about abuse she suffered at the hands of disgraced former team doctor, Larry Nassar.

She was joined by former teammates Aly Raisman and McKayla Maroney who also appeared before the committee, along with FBI Director Christopher Wray.

The committee is examining shortcomings in the FBI's investigation into Nassar, who was convicted of sexually abusing girls. He is now serving a life sentence in jail after more than 200 women gave impact statements.

A report into the FBI's investigation found numerous missteps and cover-ups by FBI agents, which allowed Nassar's abuse to continue for months after the case was first opened.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about the story.

(📷 Getty Images)

#BBCNews

node.text:
"It feels amazing to be that face that young black girls can look at and say, 'yes she did that, so we can as well.'"

Pamela Uba got in to pageants by accident, after working at the bar during a competition when one of the judges thought she was a contestant and encouraged her to start.

Now she is the first black woman in history to have been crowned Miss Ireland, with absolutely no modelling experience.

The 26-year-old medical student moved from South Africa with her family when she was 7, where they lived in accommodation for asylum seekers.

Her next step is the 2022 Miss World competition which is being held in Puerto Rico in the Caribbean.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about her story.

(📷 Brian McEvoy)

#Modelling #Ireland #SouthAfrica #BBCNews

node.text:
As governments such as the UK transition to ‘zero carbon’, countries will see the formation of new industries and ‘green’ jobs which didn’t exist a generation ago.

This transition will be a key issue at the COP26 climate talks in Glasgow in November.

Beth, 21, is a research assistant at a vertical farm which uses renewable energy to grow crops which are then sold locally.

Bridie, 23, used to work in hospitality but is now retraining as an apprentice offshore wind turbine technician.

#ClimateChange #COP26 #BBCNews

node.text:
Unsubstantiated claims made by Nicki Minaj about the Covid vaccine have been criticised by England's chief medical officer.

Prof Chris Whitty said those who knowingly spread misinformation about Covid "should be ashamed" and “many of those people... know that they are peddling untruths, but they still do it".

His comments came after the musician said a coronavirus vaccine has caused her cousin's friend's testicles to swell. 

Tap the link in our bio to read how Nicki responded - and what happened when Piers Morgan and the BBC’s political editor became involved.

(📷 PA Images / Getty) 

#NickiMinaj #BBCNews
